editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: A christian turned Turk: or, the tragical lives and deaths of the two famous pirates, ward and Dansiker.
As it hath been publicly acted.
London, printed by for William Barrenger, and are to be sold at the great north-door of Paul's. 1612.

div.head: To the knowing reader.
div.p:
As no argument more proveth the excellency of poesy than the contempt is thrown upon it by silken gulls and ignorant citizens, so there is no blemish taketh from the beauty of this only allcomprehending-art, so much as the same wherewith her own professors brand her, for I may truly vary that of the tragedian, quemcunque poetam vides, miserum dicas, I speak it especially in regard of that free title better times allowed this heavenly science, now made captive by each unworthy hand; in recovery whereof I have, so far as my weak power extended, procured the publishing this oppressed and much martyred tragedy, not that I promise to myself any reputation hereby, or affect to see my name in print, ushered with new praises, for fear the reader should call in question their judgements that give applause in the action; for had this wind moved me, I had prevented others shame in subscribing some of my former labours, or let them gone out the in devil's name alone: which since impudence will not suffer, I am content they pass together; it is then to publish my innocence concerning the wrong of worthy personages, together with doing some right to the much-suffering actors that hath caused my name to cast itself in the common rack of censure, accompanied with so weak comforts, as this trivial work can give it, and that my gratitude may be in the first place, I must in despite of any justly neglected
chronic confess to have received so much worthy respect, and approved so much generous honesty in them, that with any indifferent hazard, I will study to make good their loss, and my gratitude. I write this, led by no mercenary hopes to share in their fortunes, which hath so put out sums eyes, that measuring others sight by their own weakness gave her out for blind; but led by that spirit knoweth no sin equal to ingratitude: as for the former imputation, granting all objections, I clear myself by these two positions, no man can feign any ill of a parricide, the greater always including the less; this being so tolerable, especially in oratory, which is an unseparable branch of poesy, that it subsists not without aggravation; the second is, no man can entitle another to his crimes, for, alia est cognatio culpae, alia sanguinis, from which I so far abhor, as my own descent is not obscure but generous, if this will not give satisfaction, know I live under too safe a law to fear the stab of a roving boy, and for any wrong, equo mart, I forgive it, daring thus far to boast my knowledge, that I cannot be a coward, I write succintly, knowing the bounds of an epistle, the rather because I wish no other perusers, than those to whom I dedicate myself; though herein I speak against the printers profit, if these accept my impolished labours, I promise the next shall be cooked for the stomachs of the critical, mess itself. Sanabimur si separemur a coetu.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: All fair content dwell here, and may our strains
Give you that choice delight which crowns our pains.
Our subiect's low, yet to your eyes presents
Deeds high in blood, in blood of innocents:
Transcends them low, and your invention calls
To name the sin beyond this black deed falls.
What heretofore set others pens a-work,
Was ward turned pirate, ours is ward turned Turk.
Their trivial scenes might best afford to show
The baseness of his birth, how from below
Ambition oft takes root, makes men forsake
The good the'enjoy, yet know not. Our muse doth take
A higher pitch, leaving his piracy
To reach the heart itself of villainy.
What to that period makes the nearest way,
Our scene pursues, you must suppose his stay
Hath lately been upon the Irish shore,
Where wanting men he invites some stranger's or●
Into his bark, in height of wine and game,
He slips his anchor, and reveals his name.
There fate succeeds, and to your gentle view
We give not what we could, but what know true.
Our ship's afloat, we fear nor rocks nor sands,
Knowing we are environed with your helping hands.

div.head: Scene. i.
div.stage: Enter Ward, Gismund, Albert, Ferd. sailors rise from a table.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: I'll play no more.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Set but my hand out, here's 400. Crowns unlost yet, fortune may make them yours.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p: Fortune's a bitch, a mere strumpet, she hath turned up the ace so long, I have ne'er an eye to see with ▪ she hath soaked me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: We came aboard to venture with you,
Deal merchant-like, put it upon one main,
And throw at all.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: One cast, and we will leave you.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.l: Leave us yet? we have a cast worth two of the rest.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: 'Tis set, throw at it gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: We shall have time enough hereafter,
You are too violent.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p: I fear you'll not be half so forward anon when we should use you.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.p: A sail, a sail, a sail.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Shout.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Why stand you so amazed? conceive you not the language of the sea?

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: Now you may show yourselves gamesters,
You shall have your bellies full of hazard.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: We are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Are you not merchantmen?

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p: How else? and deal by wholesale, take up much at a long day. Do you know this honourable shape? Heroic captain ward, lord of the ocean, terror of Kings, landlord to merchants, rewarder of manhood, conqueror of the western world, to whose followers the lands and seas pay tribute, and they to none, but once in their lives to the manor of Wapping, and then are free ever after. This is he my noble mummers.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: We are for ever lost.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: If't be our moneys that you covet, willingly we give it up, only deprive us not of our fair home, our country: do but land us.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Know we have other use for you,
Have not enticed you hither for your gold,
It is the man we want. Is't not a shame,
Men of your qualities and personage,
Should live as cankers, eating up the soil
That gave you being, like beasts that never look further ▪
Then where they first took food, that men call home,
Which gives them means equal unto their minds,
Puts them in action.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: True, who is't would not smile
To hear a soldier, that hath nothing left
But misery to speak him man, can show
More marks than pence, upon whose back contempt
Heaps on the weight of poverty. Who would not smile
To hear this piece of wretchedness boast his wounds?
How far he went to purchase them? with what honour
He put them on? and now for sustenance,
Want of a little bread, being giving up
His empty soul, should joy yet that his country
Shall see him breathe his last: when that air he terms his
Ungratefully doth stifle him.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You tell us of a gulf, which to eschew,
You dash us 'gainst a rock more full of fear
Of danger: for we should call that action,
Which gives unto posterity our name
Writ in the golden lines of honour, where this brands
Our foreheads with the hateful name of thieves, of robbers,
Piracy, it's theft, most hateful, swallows up
The estates of orphans, widows, who born free,
Are thus made slaves, enthralled to misery,
By those that should defend them, at the best.
You rob the venting merchants, whose manly breast
Scorning base gain at home, puts to the main
With hazard of his life and state, from other lands
To enrich his own, whilst with ungrateful sands
He thus is overwhelmed.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: These children have been at s. Antlins.
They'll persuade's out of our profession.
A plague upon this scholarship,
One man that savours of an university,
Is able to infect a whole navy with cowardice.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Cowardice? thou liest: there's not a man here dares less than thyself.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: Zounds I'll try that.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Hold, or by all my hopes, who makes next proffer
Falls on my sword. If you will try your valours
The enemy is at hand. As for your virtuous lectures,
We are mariners, and soldiers, not tattered yet
Enough to hear them, though in time we might
Be apt for such tongue-comfort, being swayed
By your directions.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: A sail, a sail, a sail.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: How? more sails yet?

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: The first that we descried, doth bear a head,
And as it seems, pursued by a man of war,
They make with us for succour.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p: Yes, we'll succour her, and suck her too, as dry as a usurer's palm.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Nay, than we are put from shore.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.l: Without ken boys, more sails, the least delay.
O let's turn serving-men, the trencher hold
Whilst others eat the meat.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Away, make ready for the fight.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.l: Courage brave sparks, now to gain wealth, or graves:
To die in peace fits beasts, and abject slaves.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou needst not fear the curse, bloodthirsty monster.
O that our better part should thus be captived
By sense and will! who like a ship unmanned,
That's born by motion of the violent waves
And giddy winds, doth seem to make a course
Direct and punctive, till we see it dash
Against some prouder Sulla, and display
How much she inward wanted to her sway.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You have well described him: but to our own fortunes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We must obey necessity, since 'tis our fates
To be surprised thus, by this monster beast.
We must as did that captain, so much famed,
Li●k the fierce lion's feet, till happier times
Do give us freedom in his punish't crimes.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You have well advised. Fortune in spite of thee,
Howe'er my body's thralled, my mind rests free.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: This stand our comfort: we may happen be
The chorus only to their tragedy.

div.head: Scene. 2.
div.stage: Enter Lemot, his sister Alizia, putting on the weed of a sailor's boy, monsieur Davy, and sailors.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: Unfortunate sister, my heart dissolves to blood,
And pays sad tribute to thy sadder griefs.
Nay, make no period, our woes are not at full,
Hymen did never behold so black a nuptial.
Alas! with our delay we hasten misery,
See how they bear up to us. Dear sister hide
at lest thy sex, though not thy sorrow.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Wretched Alizia, little thinks young Raymond
His bride's so near unto captivity.
Be gentle yet you seas, and swallow me,
Since I am denied his arms, let my virginity
Be offered unto him in sacrifice.
'T will be some comfort, his love a maiden dies.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: Nay then thou cleavest my soul, do not distrust
Chaste thoughts are guided by a power, that's just.
My worthy friends, yet what persuasion needs
To stir up valour where necessity
And justice of our cause, in basest spirits
Would strike a fire to kindle cowardice?
Three days we have been pursued by a Dutch pirate,
And now we are fallen upon no less a monster.
Methinks I see your eyes darting forth flames
Like lions in their chase, the greedy hunter
Seeming to warm that blood, whose heat and rage
Proves his destruction.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: Hoy,

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: Not ready yet? alas thou wilt betray
Thyself unto their lust.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Rather to death: nature this comfort gave,
No place so miserable, but yields a grave
To wretchedness.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.l: Hoy, of whence your ship, and whither are you bound?

sp.speaker: Davi.
sp.l: We are of Marcelles, bound for Normandy.
Of whence are you?

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: We are of the sea.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: The devil land you.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: Bring your master a board ▪ or we'll give you a broad side.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: As you are men I do conjure your valours.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: As you are virtuous keep from slavery.
A hapless, hapless maid.

sp.speaker: Davi.
sp.l: Misdoubt it not fair-maid,
There's not a man here, but well knows how much
he hath advantage of his enemy,
A race of thieves, bankrupts, that have lain
Upon their country's stomach like a surfeit,
Whence being vomited they strive with poisonous breath
To infect the general air: creatures that stand
So far from what is man, they know no good,
But in their prey, nor for necessity
But for mere hate to virtue, pursuing vice,
And being down themselves would have none rise.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: The curs are sure asleep, we'll waken 'em,
Gunner give fire.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: In their own language answer them.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.p: Zounds do they begin to prate, have with you, lace the netting, let down the fights, make ready the small shot, gunner, give them a broad side, we'll prate with 'em a star board there.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: Brave countrymen,
Think through how many dangers, with what sweat, what care,
How long expense of time, we have been getting
Those goods these robbers fight for, that should make good to us
The sweet of just endeavours, look on this maid,
Think with what honourable welcomings,
You shall deliver her to her betrothed husband,
How much you shall engage him, lastly, think that you see,
Even all the misery's despised poverty
Can throw on men, that by this one hours valour
We only can redeem ourselves from death
O think how happy 'tis to innocence,
Whereunto guilty souls it looks black and fearful:
At least let this all thoughts of fear dispel,
Truth fights 'gainst theft, and heaven opposes hell.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We are resolved s. Dennis victory.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: A constant breast may fall, but cannot die,

div.stage: Enter Ward with a slain friend, and Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Recall thy spirit brave friend, a while, yet stay,
At least bear thy revenge hence with thee.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: He hath lost all motion.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Injurious heaven that with so excellent matter
As is our soul, didst mingle this base mould,
So frail a substance earth, as if thou hadst framed man
The subject of thy laughter, gavest him a spirit
Free, unbounded, whose fiery temper breaks
Through all the clouds of danger, dares even heaven,
Swells and bears high, when with one little prick
This bubble breaks, displays a vanity,
Ridiculous vanity, this building
That hath been twenty and odd years a rearing,
One blast thus lays it flat, I could e'en tremble,
To think that such a coward I bear about me,
As is this flesh, that for so small a wound
Betrays our life.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: This shows sir, nature ne'er intended man,
Other then as she sent him to the world,
All unoffensive, unaligned: when unto beasts ,
She gave the means to hurt as to defence,
The armour she gave man was innocence.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: True, there was some other end in our creation
Then to be that which men term valiant.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: There was.

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: Courage brave sparks the slaves begin to faint,

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: It is his evil spirit sure that in this likeness haunts him

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: See where he lies.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.l: 'Sfoot we shall share the more sir, I always thought
Fortune had marked him out to die by the French.
He had so much of the English spirit in him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Fortune ▪ true, the fate of man is fixed,
Unmoveable as the pole: how idle then were he
Should strive to cross unvoided destiny?
And think to stay his course, seeing we are swayed
As are the motionary engines of a clock,
By the dull weight that still doth downward tend,
Till it strike earth, and so there motion end.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Give me the hearing sir,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Persuade no more, we have no will to act,
Or not to act more, than those orbs we see,
And planetary bodies, which in their offices
Observe the will of fate: the difference is,
They are confined, we are not ▪ they are stars fixed,
We wand'ring run on thou purple line
That drawest my life's fate out, thou that dost frown
Upon the births of men, now Saturn smile.
Those under milder planets born live, servile: good;
Mars called our birth, my race shall be through blood

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Abused knowledge that first wert given to man
A light, now helpest to dazzle him, and whate'er want
Befall through our own imperfect judgement,
Unbridled will the throw on fortune, chance,
I see man's happiness, were his ignorance,

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.l: A board, a board, a board.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Dear sir withdraw, you are deprived of sight

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: So much the better, I see no fear in fight,
Courage brave countrymen: what's nature's part
May fall; what's heaven's can never, it is the odds
That just men have of bad, still to the gods
They stand or fall.

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.l: Enter, enter ▪ enter.
Zounds the slave winks and fights.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: A ward, a ward, a ward,
sp.p: Down with them, down with them, away let him go overboard, where he a second Alexander, there's not a man of them lives, but shall go overboard, we'll offer them to our deceased friends in sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: My brother, my dear dear brother.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: There were no conscience, no religion in't,

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.p: How? Conscience, were't but to banish those two words they shall go overboard.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: They shall go overboard: suppose I speak the contrary.

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.p:
My captain, my man of war speak the contrary
they are as safe as the great Turk.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Now they shall overboard.

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.l: Out-swaggered?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: How many French are left?

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: There's only five of four and twenty living.
Never did men with equal spirit stand,
A day so black and stormy: rob not yourself then,
Of so brave witnesses of this day's valour.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: How? dare you sir give us directions?

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: How dare I sir? I am a gentleman
Equal unto yourself.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Take that now, I am before you,

sp.speaker: Gism.
sp.l: You are, I'll not be long behind you.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Know, that our word shall be a law,

sp.speaker: Gallip.
sp.p: That may be, for he hath had conscience by the ears already.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Hoist me a vessel up of maligo,
We'll drink a health unto the wand'ring ghosts
Of our slain followers, and every draught
The cannon makes report off, a Frenchman
Shall overboard, who to our friends may tell,
We drank a rouse to them,

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: As low as hell.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.p: Francisco captain of the man of war, pursued our prize, hath set a pinnace forth, who according to the custom of the sea, demands half of the spoil, to your demand he threatens instant fight, force against force, or if you dare to accept it, he makes you offer of single opposition.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Accept it? he could not name that honour
We covet more, reward the messenger,
They two shall be the hostages
For the equal trial, what's his weapon?
Where the place of fight?

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: His weapons are sword and dagger, the place
Here on our hatches, both our ships being grappled,
The cath on each side given, who conquers the other
Shares the whole booty.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Agreed we seal to his condition,
Francisco call you him? I emulate
His daring spirit.

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.l: Fortune shapes our revenge you see.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: What need you give yourself unto this danger,
When in our general strength we have advantage?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I prithee do not move my patience, I scorn to take
From others to my rising, he's only worthy state
From fortune's wheel plucks boldly his own fate,
And here's an arm shall do't.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: You see his insolence how he contemns us.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: No more, we are agreed.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.l: How shall we hinder their pursuit?

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.l: When both the ships are grappled, privately
We'll cut their hawsers, the wind blows fair
To give our lesser bark advantage, 'tis not ten leagues
To Tunis, where entered, we are as safe
As in a tower of brass.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.l: How if we shoot him, as we make away?

sp.speaker: Gallop.
sp.l: By no means to shall be Francisco's task
To cut his throat, this makes our revenge full,
We share the prize he fights for

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.l: Rare gull! we are all firm and secret,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: All.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: So that I rise, let the world sink, heaven fall.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: My merit: shall I thrall them? the sway of things,
Belongs to him dares most, such should be Kings,
And such am I, what nature in my birth
Denied me, fortune supplies: this maxim I hold,
He lives a slave, that lives to be controlled,
But see the man whose ruin crowns me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Art thou the chief and guider of this bark?

sp.speaker: Ward,
sp.l: The same sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: May I impute it to your ignorance
In marines' actions, or the daring spirit,
That bars my right in thy achieved prize.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: This makes you answer, what do you see in me,
doth promise I should be the sutler sir,
Fetch you provision in.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A little calmer sir, you are not now in Kent,
Crying herrings seven a penny, nay we have heard of you ▪
You can bawl well, you have served a prenticeship
Unto the trade, affrighting of whole streets
With your full oyster voice.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Poor fisher's brat, that never didst aspire
Above a mussel boat, that wert not born
Unto a fortune 'bove two cades of sprats,
And those smoked in thy father's bedchamber ▪
That by a beggar in mere charity
Being made drunk, steed of a mariner
Wert stole aboard, and being awake didst smell
Worse than thy shell commodity at midsummer,
That desperate through fear wert made a captain,
When to have been ashore again, thou wouldst have turned
Swabber unto a peterman.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: By all my hopes thou hadst been better digged
Thy grandsires urn up and have swallowed it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Thou barkest too much to bite.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Clear the deck there, each man bestow himself

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.l: It's done, there hawser's cut without descry,

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Away, farewell brave captain, conquest sits on thy brow.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Leave me, I say

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Th'wert never gulled till now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Give a charge there, say your prayers knight, doom's day is nigh

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: True it sinks thee to hell, whilst thus it bears me high.
Standest thou so long, thou hast some enchantment sure,
Or have I lost my wonted vigour?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Flatter no more thyself, wilt thou deliver
A moiety of thy prize up?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Yes, thus thou sharest it: damnation! his sword falls.
O that my gall could spout out through mine eyes
A poisonous vapour to put out your lights,
and in a vale of darkness leave the world.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Wilt thou yet yield me right?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Know Francisco,
Wert thou an army that encompassed me,
I would breathe defiance to thee, and with this arm,
As shot from out a cannon's mouth, thus would I make
A way through death and danger.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I do applaud thee, and that thou well mayst know
All valour's not confined within thy breast
sp.stage: He flings away his sword, and after loseth his dagger.
sp.l: I thus oppose thee, fortune shall have no share
In what I conquer.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Why, now I envy thee, thy life is mine,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Take it I dare thy let.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Not for the world, thus I return thy debt:
Not only in the prize but in myself
Thou hast an equal share, henceforth I vow the brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Your love, I ask no more.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: You need not, there's one gone before
Takes order for your share.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Whether makes the slaves, where's Gallop?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Posting as fast as his sails will bear him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Incarnate devil forthwith give them chase,
Why movest not?

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: They have cut our hawsers we cannot budge a foot.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: The death of slaves pursue him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You are too violent.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: To be baffled by a cur, a foisting hound
My zany: a creature without a soul
Made to mock man with.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Forbear I say, and let us turn our anger
On the next passenger.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Might I but live to see the dogfish once again.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Near doubt it sir, next prize we take forthwith
We'll make to Tunis, mean time let revenge sleep
Those tides most violent are, which winds back keep,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: For this alone I vow, whom next I meet
Shall feel my fury, nation nor quality
shall be their privilege, my sword now vengeance craves,
And who escape this do worse, I'll sell for slaves.

div.head: Scoen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Dansiker, three or four sailors, lieutenant Dansiker reads a letter.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: What news brave captain?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Good. These letters from my wife bring certainty
Of our obtained pardons, on condition
We hence forth for the state of France employ
Our lives and service.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Long live King Henry of France.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: My valiant friends this 4 years Dansiker
Hath led you proudly through a sea of terror,
Through deeds so full of prowess they might have graced
The brow of worthiness, had justice to our cause
Given life and action. But since the breach of laws
Of nations, civil society, justly entitles us
With the hateful style of robbers, let's redeem our honour
And not return into our country, with the names
Of pardoned thieves, but by some worthy deed,
Daring attempt, make good unto the world
Want of employment, not of virtue forced
Our former act of spoil and rapine.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Set the design down may regain us credit
Deserve this grace so freely offered us
We'll or accomplish it, or with our lives
Seal the attempt.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Brave captain, through death we'll follow thee,

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Then thus, that with the same weapon, we may
Our country cure, with which we wounded her,
My purpose is to ruin all the pirates
Lie in the harbour here.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Rarely it may be easy done, observe the wind
And firing but of one consume the rest.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: We must not trust to such incertainties.
Thus I have plotted it: we first will set a fire
Some house ith' town, to which when each man makes,
As they will be enforced from the haven
To yield their helps, with much facility
We may perform our purpose.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: How? undescried, shall we attempt the town?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: That charge be mine, the renegado Jew,
You know gives free and open entertain
To all of our profession. In some outhouse of his
I will convey a pot of wildfire to it,
I'll make a train of match, that at three hours
Shall give it fire.

sp.speaker: Sailors.
sp.l: Excellent! The time sir.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Tomorrow night: mean time make ready
For our departure, but with such secrecy
Suspicions self may not descry it: provide the balls
We must bestow upon the ships.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: That care be ours.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: The rest leave unto me,
We'll return nobly, or else nobly die.
Reuben, what news?

sp.speaker: Rub.
sp.l: My master sir, desires your company,
There's a new pirate landed, his name is Gallop.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: More yet? do they come on so fast?
Your master would in gross his prize.

sp.speaker: Rub.
sp.l: He would: and for your courtesy herein,
He will forbear three months the crowns you owe him:

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: I'll use my art sir to his benefit,
And for the crowns, no longer I'll delay him,
Here is my hand tomorrow night I'll pay him.

div.head: Scene. 4.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Speak freely, what think you of the new-come captain,
Voada?

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p: He looks as if his father and mother had got him in fear: his eyes go like a city catchpoles, several ways at once, there's no stuff in him. Give me the Dutch cavalier Dansiker.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Out upon him puff-paste, he was spoilt in his infancy, ill-bred.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: How? spoiled with ill bread? it was ill drink spoiled him. I am of my master's mind, the new-come pirate is a reasonable handsome man of a christian.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Why? doth religion move any thing in the shapes of men?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Altogether. What's the reason else that the Turk and Jew is troubled (For the most part) with gouty legs, and fiery nose, to express their heartburning: whereas the Puritan is a man of upright calf, and clean nostril.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p: Setting aside your nose, you should turn christian, than your calf swells upward mightily.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: How? I turn christian? they have Jew enough already amongst 'em: were it but three qualities they have, I'll be none of their society.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Three qualities? I prithee tell 'em us Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: First, they suffer their wives to be their masters. Secondly, they make men thieves for want of maintenance, and then hang them up for stealing. Lastly, they are mad four times a year, and those they call term-times, and then they are so purged by their physicians, which they name lawyers, some of 'em are never their own men after it. I turn christian? they shall have more charity amongst 'em first. They will devour one-another as familiarly as pikes do gudgeons, and-with as much facility as Dutchmen do flapdragons.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: How? eat up one-another?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Ay, eat up one-another: you have an innocent christian called a gallant, your city christian will feed upon no other meat by his good will.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p: But their wives will not feed on 'em too.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: The truth is, they are not altogether so great devourers; marry they will be sucking at the bones. But see my master, the great thief and the little thieves, the robbers and the receiver.

div.stage: Enter Jew, Gallop, Das. Sar. Sis.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: He's come. Thou powerful god of love, strike through
Those awful darts of thine, whose burning heads (Mine eyes
Pierce through hearts of ye, melt frostiest breasts,
Make all stoop to thy deity. Now give thy art,
No god but Cupid pities mortal's smart.

div.stage: Enter Dansiker, benwash, Jew, Gismund, Frederick, Carolo, Alizia.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.l: Five ducats a tun, 'Shart the cask is worth more,

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: You must remember at what rate you bought 'em.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: And at what price you may have more.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.l: You speak like men that know how the market goes
Your ear Jew.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: What misery remains to add to mine,
My brother lost his life in my defence;
And with his life, my sex and liberty,
I stand deprived of. Are not these wounds sufficient
To let out my weak breath? Thou flinty breast,
Art thou impenetrable? or is that thing called death
Too great a good for such a wretch as I am? It is, it is,
And that's the cause so many miseries
Do stop the way to't.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: I am your merchant Reuben Rabshake, my wife, her sister fetch me three hundred ducats for this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.l: This new-come thief sir?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Gentleman, slave.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Why your thief is a gentleman, he scorns to do any thing, and he lives upon his comings in.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Peace dog, you see gallants, we are not italianate to lock our women up, we set 'em free, give open entertainment.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
It seems this Jew keeps a bawdy-house, I like his wife
well, I could find in my heart to cast away half a ducat on her.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: You are of a noble mind sir, courtly and high,
It's want of merit that breeds jealousy,
From which I know you clear.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: As I am from covetousness: how their eyes strike each other? Rabshake —

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Captain, your gold.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: He saw our eyes meet, no matter, may I cool my heat let the world burn. Thy counsel Voada.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: I do not like this fellow's looks, Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.l: He hath a hanging countenance indeed sir,

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Tush, my wifeman, thou hast forgotten how dear
I bought my liberty, renounced my law,
The law of Moses, turned Turk, all to keep
My bed free from these Mahometan dogs.
I would not be a monster Rabshake, a man-beast,
A cuckold.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I have not forgotten sir that you damned yourself because you would not be a cornuto: if every man should fine so dear for his horns, we should have but a few Christians left: but seeing you fear your vessel hath a leak, wherefore do you put her to sea, man her thus?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: For commodity: thou seest rich shopkeepers set their wives at sale to draw in custom, utter their wares, yet keep that gem untouched: all for profit man.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I am not of your mind sir, there is no profit without some pain.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: No more villain: should I suspect myself to have that disease, I would run mad, first fury of my horns should light on thee: look to't, thou art no longer living than my wife is honest.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I fear my days are but short then, if my life lasts no longer than I can keep a woman honest against her will.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: It is a lovely boy, rare featured, would he were mine.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: It is so Voada, he hath made the slave my jailor.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: I have not seen so much of beauty in a man.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: You lose yourself. What man? what beauty? I tell thee I am undone, Rabshake is made my overseer.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p: I would use him like an overseer then, he should stand by whilst the executioner opened the bags: I must enjoy his love, though quenching of my lust did burn the world besides.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: It's right captain.

sp.speaker: Gis.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis right.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: But that's the wrong way sir, your followers expect their equal shares.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: The fellow raves: talk to a captain of equal sharing, I'll take order for landing the goods, and be with you presently. Rabshake, thou knowest thy doom slave, look to't, thine eyes, villain thine eyes.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I'll warrant you sir, I'll look to't.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Here, carry 'em these two ducats to drink upon receipt of the whole, I'll deal like a commander with 'em, as men do with their followers: that is, as you have followed me to earn means, so now you shall follow me as long to get your earnings, you shall be followers still, I will discharge none of you.

sp.speaker: Sares.
sp.p: We took him for a gull, but now I see he hath had command, he can cheat his soldiers.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: I hope sir you will make better respect of your credit, you know your oaths and promise.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: My promise, if a citizen had bought a company, he could but keep day with 'em: you must pardon him gentlemen, a fresh soldier wants seasoning.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: Salt us, look to't, we shall hardly relish you sir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How? threatens and braves?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: Forbear, give the poor fellow leave to prate, he pays for't.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: Good: you are now upon your guard, we shall meet you upon discharge of the watch, and knock you down with a bill of accounts, we shall skeld.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Out gull, talk to a commander, a man of war of equal
sharing, we have other use for our money then to pay followers. Shall we accost these ladies, gallants?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: 'Tis the custom of the whole world, the greater thief preys upon the less still: how's this?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: The happiness of the day befall you I adyes.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: The night equal the days-happiness, say I.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: All content both night and day stand to your desires

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Our desires equal your wishes sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Your desires are above my performance then.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I am drawing on, if my life lie upon her honesty, I am upon the point of giving up already.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: That gentleman is very moving.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Could you not entreat him stay his pace.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: And trot in your ring, lady, if you please.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: I purpose not to take a courser of your choosing, lest I be jaded sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You presume the more of your own horsemanship.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Heyday, they are riding already, 'sfoot I am like to go post to the devil for this.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: Next night, time of my project, if I prove not as hot a shot as came in your quarters since the loss of your virginity, let me suffer the pains of s. Anthony's purgatory.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: He must necessarily be a man of deeds, he is of so few words.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You shall do well to put him to the trial.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Without immodesty, may I question the reason you're so heavy sir?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Nay then it rings out for me, should the Jew see this, I were as good as speechless: there were but a little gasping between me and the grave.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: The reason of my heaviness is, that you and I might agree the better: for women love contraries, and you are light I see.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: How's this? you see me light, true, to be in love with one so far disdainful.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.p: What success woman? the Dutchman and I have bartered wares

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: I have made exchange too, sold my liberty,
to purchase base ingratitude, I am rejected Voads.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: My mistress, gentlemen, did you see my mistress?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Your business sirrah?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: You must make provision to entertain two of the richest pirates ever landed here, one captain ward and Franciscus, they have brought a prize in worth three thousand ducats: besides, they sell their prisoners slaves, my master hath engrossed them all.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Vengeance seize him and them. Back sirrah, say we will expect them: you sir, attend your master his coming, see you give us notice on't.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Nay, I hold it the best course too, for mine own safety. My charge is charged my watch must be now, lest my master know it. If all the world were eyes, women I see would to it.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: I do but dream sure, ward and Franciscus?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: What moves this passion?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Why look you pale?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Pale? I have a cause, I have less colour by 600 ducats then I had.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: As how sir?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: I'll tell you: I took an adventure to pay this ward, 600 ducats at our two meetings at Tunis, and see how the devil hath brought it about: I must leave you gallants.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: By no means: we will compound the business.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: I can conceal it no longer.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: You will betray yourself to their contempt, by your own forwardness.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: I ne'er shall have so fair occasion to speak my love again, you know my husband's watchful jealousy.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: Now by my sex I am ashamed of you, were the Jew mine,
I would have no other pander: be ruled by me
It's he shall hire the captain to thy love,
And his own horning. What cannot we persuade?
Man was asleep when woman's brain was made.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.l: Thou givest me a new life, I am thy scholar.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: I'll prick thee forth a lesson, whose choicer strain,
Shall tell men that all art 'gainst lust and women's vain.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: As you are men conceal your weapons, here are women in the room.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Sismund.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.l: We are come to give you thanks for the 2 ducats sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: As you are of the sword, draw.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.l: We are freshmen, we'll powder you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Murder, murder, I shall be torn in pieces, by my hands.

div.stage: Enter Ward, Franciscus, Ferd. Al. page.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.l: Ward, Franciscus, we are betrayed, away.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Gallop.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: My noble general alive, come to my rescue, my loyalty to the brave knight did thus engage me: the slaves could not be content to stow me underboard, and force me from thee, but would have shared the prize too: but I have shared with 'em, see here's three hundred ducats, thou shalt have them all brave spark, the devil to boot with 'em.

sp.speaker: Vvard
sp.p: Then you think this gold shall purchase your pardon.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: 'Sfoot I am overjoyed with the fight of thee: see the heroic Dansiker, his captain Sar●.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.p: Your loves, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: This is no slave, he pays 600. ducats at their meeting, true, we are witness on't.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.p: I will be guled for once thus, I will, these ducats shall stop my mouth.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: 'sheart there are as many more in bank, you shall have 'em all, I prize thy countenance above a second Indies, were they molten in your garbage. The world runs round with me, sicut erat in principio, naked I came in, and pennyless I shall go out.
sp.l: What stays the Jew so long,

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: See he is come.
sp.stage: Enter Jew, Raymond, his two sons bound. Ruben.
sp.l: You'll give my price sir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Yes, for these slaves, I will.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: For ever be he servile that so makes 'em.
Hard-hearted; man, I cannot term thee, it's
A name that bears too much of pity in't,
Compared with so inhumane; creature wert thou a father,
These tears would move thee, that bemoan a son's,
Nay all my children's, worse than funeral,
Their ever thraldom, but nature well denied
Issue to thee, lest in thy barbarous guilt
She had been a party. When thy affectioned soul
Had felt how much the name of child moves, with what care,
How many jealous fears we view there infancy,
Lest having felt all this, thy accursed hand
Should yet have dared to make men childless.

sp.speaker: 1. Son.
sp.l: Can then your marble heart endure these drops?

sp.speaker: 2. Son.
sp.l: The soil that bred you sir doth not bring forth
Such hideous monsters, that we should imagine
You can be so far cruel to betray
So many innocent lives, for in us bleed
An aged father, a mother, to whose grief
No other misery can be added.
Myself contracted to a virtuous maid,
Who ere this hath left Marcel,
And in Normandy expects the consummation of our happiness.
You have our goods, our ship, all the substance
Should succour our old parents, you have only left
These arms to earn them bread, and can your eyes
Relentless see these chained?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Do not they move you sir?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Yes, as the Jew, art not thou moved Benwash?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: As a hangman at an execution makes no other holiday in the year.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Inhuman dog! o I could tear thee villain,

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: I'll give thirty crowns for this old beast to be revenged on him.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Be gentle, take his money, forgive me sir,
I see you are kind, would not now part us
That twenty and odd years have grown together,
Will you not take it? give him so Jew,
I will deserve 'em, see I am not old,
No wrinkle is on my brow, these are but frowns,
Raised by his unkind refusal of my offer.
See what plump veins I have, no sinews shrunk,
These are not gray-hairs, they are only white
To show the lightness of my spirit: come
Manacle these arms, you shall see us three
Tug the day's eye out, there's not a father
And his two boys shall dare to undertake us,
The sun outvied we'll set us down together
And with our sadder cheer out-mourn the night,
And speak the happiness we might have lived too:
How by mine own hearth in cold wintereves
I might have told my sons some ancient tales,
Which they might one day from their grandsire speak.
We'll add unto our woes thus by compare
Of what our joys might have been, then we'll curse,
And when we want a plague, we'll think upon
This bloody murderer, we shall have store then:
Be eloquent in bitter execrations,
Our choler vented, then again we'll weep,
Till tears glue up our eyes to mock sad sleep.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 1. Son.
sp.l: Dost laugh at aged sorrow? be just ye powers,
As ye judge innocents causes, revenge ours.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: My money for 'em Jew, so, away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Alb. Ferd.
sp.l: We will redeem them, pay their ransom,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: You redeem them? your means?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: All that we have a board,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Such another syllable, I'll make a sale of you to.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: I am your first man, I'll give you 400 crowns for 'em

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: A sale of us?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Know that if all our fortunes will set them free, 'tis theirs.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I'll try that, give me 400 crowns.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Hear.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: They are yours, I'll justify the sale,

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Of your own fellows, countrymen do they not stand conditioned as yourself.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Who gave you patent to examine him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Forbear, because you're men of action I'll descend
To give you notice they are my lawful prize,
Such as denied my party, would willingly
Betray me, yea all of us ▪ into the hands
Of our vowed enemies.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Are you not men of war then?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: We are no pirates sir, our country yields us
More honest means of living.

sp.speaker: Sar. Om.
sp.p: Away with; 'em more honest means of livings make 'em sure,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Give us the hearing.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Away with 'em. Zounds I'll set them free else.

sp.speaker: 2. Son.
sp.l: Let's take our father's blessing with us yet.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: All curses under heaven go with you.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Is there no ear for misery to beat at?
My sons, Frederick, Albert, they are gone, sent
To perpetual vassalage, I loved you boys
A little better than to outlive your slaveries.
I will not curse thee monster, I know my thoughts
Cannot arrive unto so black revenge,
As shall attend thee: crack, crack, you o'erloaden strings,
And set a miserable old man free,
So, so, I will appeal for you my sons to yo● high court
Here none but beasts of prey tigers resort.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: I hate this villain, he's all blood.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My heart I think would break
But that in steed of words, mine eyes thus speak.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: How is't my noble spirits dulled with one tragedy,
Let us digest it with a gig, a catch.
Some wine there, shall we to hazard?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: I willingly would stake my life to thine at that just game, there wants but an occasion.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: What's your sport?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Adam's game at one whole, every male to his female

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: How should we be furnished?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: I'll fit you with an Eve sir, a temptress,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: What is she?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Your peer, a beauty that would take you
From out yourself to gaze at her,
The Jews wife's sister.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: First sight of her yields thee a 100 ducats.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: I'll be a conjunction copulative to join you together for the money, it is a fate follow's us soldiers when we are down: the reason is, we hold it no shame to live upon spoil of the enemy, and a greater foe to man then a whore is impossible s'hart I am prevented, the Jew panders them himself, that's she sir, that Turks her brother, his name is Crosman.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: The slave hath a goat in his looks.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: That's he in the Judas beard, use but thy art he's thine.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: If I liked not his 30 thousand ducats, better than's person, I would never strain my complexion for him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: She equals thy commends indeed, so true a fair I ne'er beheld till now.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Nay more to entice me, this well stuffed purse
He did enforce upon me, but 'tis your sin,
So you have profit, all religious laws
Must suffer violence, your wife be exposed
Unto all undergoers.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Forgiveness honest wife, my chaste, chaste, wife.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Nay, use your pleasure, you had best keep the gold
To guild your shame with, I trow I would give it him,
Tell him he must not think I am the woman
He takes me for, if he will not believe you,
Let him make trial with the ladder of ropes
He vowed to climb my chamber with, this night,
When, as it seems, he learned you were enforced
To be in the synagogue.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Better and better, I cannot but admire thy chastity
A ladder of ropes, would he make that the beginning
lechery should be the end of, I'll hamper him,
If he have any grace thy honesty overthrows him,

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: If he have any wit it will I hope.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: My dull eyed villain Rabshake saw none of this, he's all for reminre, he would have me a cuckold by law forsooth, by statute law, I shall put you a book case, for he shall moot I'll prize him but to the present business. Noble captain to express how much you are welcome, my wife and sister, laying all rites aside, and customary observes, come to invite you to a mean banquet sir.

sp.speaker: Vvard,
sp.l: Best thanks sir, your welcomes prodigal,
I am already feasted in this bounteous dish sir.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.p: But you are not likely to surfeit on it, I'll have a finger in the platter with you, were you the great Turk's self.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: With me, I tell thee Dansiker
Thou dost not merit with thy lips to touch
sp.stage: Sar. Dans. against Francisco, Gal. and Cros. parts them, Jew hides himself.
sp.l: So choice a rarity, what darest thou for her?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: What thou dar'st not.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I'll put that to the trial,

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: As you come of women.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: By, all the rites you owe our sex, as you are men enforce them part.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Respect the place, you are in danger of law.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: You shall o'ersway me lady, we shall meet again sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: So you are men

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Are they gone?
sp.p: What hard fortune attends me? that none of their throats were cut, I might have seized their goods, not so much as the flesh biter, but is come of.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: S'hart, this poverty makes a man valiant, when I had my ducats I had no more heart than a Jew.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: And that was the reason you so willingly parted with 'em sir

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Old, Benwash, where hidst thou thy head in this day of battle man?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Here under this table, did you think I am so branch●●
No roof would give me covering, I am but a pricket,
A mere sorrel, my head's not hardened yet
though thanks unto your mastership your fire was not wanting

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: You speak in hebrew I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Yet you can speak the whoremasters language passing well; what made you sir take my wife for a flesh-seller, a whore?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: You are abused sir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: By thee lecher, you know not this purse, this gold?
You have your tricks to climb up cuckolds haven,
Your ladder of ropes, you had best keep that hour,
My wife this night expects you: my absence
Will be enforced, she bid me tell you so,
Insatiate goat thou thinkst our wives are such,
As are your holy fisters, religious votaries,
Your spittle nuns, here take your ill got trash,
May I but know thou once more temp'st my wife,
You shall not need a ladder, I'll mount you sir a Christians
I will, you oxgall, I will.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Ha, this is gold.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Do you hear sir, hereafter know a Turk's wife from
You are one of those hold all women bound
Under the domination of the moon;
All wavering, now you have seen one of the sun sir,
Constant you slave, and as she is, with us are millions more.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Benwash, brother, 'sfoot I have sought each nook of the house for you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: It is beyond my thoughts, imaginations drowned in't ▪

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Rare, doth she plead chastity?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Like a bawd that would put off a virginity, the knight is as good as ours already, besides I have procured the governor in person to regreet him
sp.l: All that art can by ambition, lust, or flattery do,
Assure yourself this brain shall work him to.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Nay if the flesh take hold of him, he's passed redemption
He's half a Turk already, it's as good as done
Woman is hell out, in we ne'er return.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Were not I confident of my good parts, this gold would buy me out of my five senses, a full purse, a ladder of ropes, and his wife in the tail on't able to overcome any man
breathing, yet what should I fear that have so many good angels about me? sure she's in love with me, it is no other, and out of her honesty it seems she hath vowed to do nothing, but what she dares acquaint her husband with, if she have made him usher his own crest I'll swear she is a woman of the sun, she hath dazzled his eyes well, this night makes the trial, I'll take your instructions Jew, climb the matter of preferment.
sp.l: It may be 'twas my destiny gave me this crown,
Women and ropes should raise me, that put others down.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I am o'ercharged sir with so high a favor
As your descending thus to visit me.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: You are the man we covet, whose valour
Hath spoke you, so impartial worthy,
We should do wrong to merit, not gracing you.
Believe me sir, you have injured much yourself,
Vouchsafing familiarity with those
Men of so common rank as Dansiker,
Your hopes should fly a pitch above them,

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: It may be that our clime stands not to give
That full content, the air you drew at home,
And therefore purpose shortly a return.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I know no country I can call home
What by your courtesy I might, my desert stands
Not to make promise of.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Detract not from yourself, call this your own
I see there speaks a fortune in your brow
Will make us proud to have acknowledged you.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: I'll gauge a thousand ducats on equal terms,
I live to see him the sultan's admiral.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Why not as well as the great customer,
My allied kinsman governor, neither born Turks,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I dare not look so high, yet were I employed,
What a poor christian could, I durst make promise of.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Christian or Turk you are more wise I know
then with religion to confine your hopes.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: He's too well read in poesy to be tied
In the slaves fetters of religion.
What difference in me as I am a Turk,
And was a christian? life, liberty,
Wealth, honour, they are common unto all?
If any odds be, 'tis on mahomet's side,
His servit o'er thrive best I am sure.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Is this the hook your golden bait doth cover?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: I have oft with laughter thought how innocent
My thoughts when first I turned were, how scrupulous
I was, when with one argument I was confirmed; as thus,
If this religion were so damnable
As others make it, that God which owes the right
Profaned by this would soon destroy it quite.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: That's easily answered, heaven is merciful,
By their destruction it should take all means
From giving possibility to their change,
And so unjustly damn 'em ▪ but for my part,
It is not divinity but nature moves me,
Which doth in beasts force them to keep their kind.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: But men that have two ends, safety and profit,
Where beasts no farther are transported
Then with the present object, must make their actions.
Turn to those points.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Both which are in some sort proposed to you.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: As thus, for profit, you cannot with yourself
Imagine, that your virtue can be smothered,
Might there but be assurance of your trust.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How should I give you that? Gou. As we did; turn Turk.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: That were the way to more uncertainty,
Men sooner open foes then feigned friends try
And where men's acts from their own ends proceed,
More look unto those ends then like the deed,

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: This gudgeon will not bite.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: But when there are examples plentiful,
to instance 'gainst your words, you need not fear,
Men what they see oppose 'gainst what they hear.

sp.speaker: Vvar.
sp.l: The cunning fowler to beguile the birds
Brings up some tame, and lets them fly abroad
To draw in others, that their liberty
May be the bait to others misery.
Such is state-policies, sometimes to advance an ill,
When others for less crimes it oft doth kill.
But to cut off your further argument
What's mine of prowess, or art, shall rest by you
To be disposed of: but to abjure
My name, and the belief my ancestors
Left to my being. I do not love so well
The earth that bore me, to lessen my contempt
And hatred to her, by so much advantage,
So oblique act as this should give to her.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Work in my sister presently.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: You are yourself free, nor will I further
Dissuade your resolution, nor less esteem
Your merit, and fair worth.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: You engage me to you sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: He enjoys too much by promise to be won,
'Tmust be a woman's act, to whom there's naught
That is impossible: what devils dare not move.
Men to accomplish, women work them to.
And see, in happy time she's come, we'll single them.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Here comes an argument that would persuade
A god turn mortal, until I saw her face,
I never knew what men term beauty was:
Besides whose fair, she hath a mind so chaste
A man may sooner melt the Alps then her.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: We will along with you, when makes she hence?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: The wind sits fair, the slaves are sending down
Whom the next morn bears hence.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: We will aboard with you fair sir, we'll leave
Our love exchanged with you, some happier time
May perfect that good work I wish were mine.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: My truest services: nay lady stay
Though hitherto I have been a hapless orator,
Your milder measure, or my love-taught tongue,
May find more fortunate hours: for by that guide,
Which rules and knows our thoughts —

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Reserve your oaths sir to more easy ears,
I understand myself too well to credit 'em.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Ungentle maid to triumph in my torment,
If ever breast did feel the power of love,
Or beauty made a conquest of poor man
I am thy captive, by heaven, by my religion.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: As my belief's in that, my faith gives trust
To your protests.

sp.speaker: Vvar.
sp.l: Then by thy god, by the great Mahomet.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: Too weak a bond to tie a christian in.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: What shall I swear by? propose an oath to me
The breach whereof would at once sink me lower
Than hell knows being, I'll take it willingly.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: I'll be concealed no longer, know then I love,
But not the man whose daily orisons
Invoke confusion on me, whose religion
Speaks me an infidel.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: 'Sheart I am of none, only to feed discourse,
And fill up argument.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: But you must be of one if you'll enjoy me,
If then your thoughts answer to what you speak
Turn Turk I am yours.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Turn Turk?

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: Do you demur already? how prodigal your words
Spoke your affection, and with one simple trial
Are you struck mute.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: With patience hear me lady.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: False knight, I have given too calm an ear already
To thy enchanted notes.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Should I for ever sell my liberty?

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: You need not, it is sufficient glory
You have betrayed a maiden's liberty.
But I'll do penance for my so black a sin,
Doting on thee, I'll henceforth hate thy whole sex;
The name of man to me, shall as the rock
From which the shipwrecked wretch hath lately 'scaped
Bring fear in the name of't: keep off false Siren.
Heaven well ordained man should the woman woe,
Should we their hard-hearts prove, we all ill should know.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Stay, I will enforce thee else.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Do these my tears delight thee then? cruel
Hard-hearted man, glut thy relentless sight
With full-eyed sorrow.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: She is all amorous, all fair, that she doth love,
Behold those tears whose drops would pierce the hearts
Of tigers, make them pitiful,
They are witnesses she feigns not: leave, leave to weep,
Lest putting out those lights the world should mourn.
Put on a veil of black, I am thine own.
If there be any divinity, it hath
His seat in beauty: thou'rt a God to me
My country, friends, nay being, what wouldst thou have.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: To be no other than myself I crave.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I am no more mine own, rather than lose
So true a happiness, as thy constant love,
There is no way so black I would not prove,
That lies from heaven to hell. Crosman in vain
Thy arguments were spent wouldst thou prevail?
Here is an orator can turn me easily,
Where beauty pleads, there needs no sophistry.
Thou hast o'ercome me Voada.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: And I will raise thee but thou dost name a good,
I cannot call mine till I am possessed of 't.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Call in thy friends, make preparation,
I'll take the orders instantly,
My speed shall give prevention to the prate
Of th'idle multitude: away, the flame doth burn
Which sets the world on fire, and makes me turn.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Thou art all harmony, best love I fly,
I have my ends,
How ere thou sink, thy wealth shall bear me high.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: So, the day leaves the world, chaste Voada
Nothing can make him miserable enjoys thee:
What is 't I lose by this my change? my country,
Already 'tis to me impossible,
My name is scandaled? what is one island
Compared to the Eastern monarchy? this large
Unbounded station shall speak my future fame;
Besides, they are slaves stand subject unto shame.
One good I enjoy, outweighs all ills whatever
Can be objected; to sum my happiness:
That God on earth, to whom all men stand bare,
(Gold) that doth usher greatness, lackeys me,
I have more than I can spend, what wants
Is in command, and that my valour makes
Due purchase of, I'll rather lead on slaves
Then be commanded by the power of Kings.
Beauty, command, and riches, they are these three
The world pursues, and these do follow me.
Speak, what news Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The tongues of ravens are too mild to speak it,
The very thought where of methinks should turn
Your hair to quills of porcupines, it's the denial
Of your redeemer ▪ religion, country,
Of him that gave you being.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: The slavery of man, how this religion rides us!
Deprives us of our freedom from our cradles,
Ties us in superstitious bondage.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Heaven stop mine ears from hearing thy dishonour.
Upon my knees I do conjure you sir,
Sell not your soul for such a vanity,
As that which you term beauty, eye-pleasing idol,
Should you with the renouncing of your god
Taking the abhorred name of Turk upon you,
Purchase a little shameful being here, your case
might be compared to his, who adjudged to death
By his heads loss, should ●rave (Stead of one stroke)
To die a lingering torment on the rack.
Even such would be your life, whose guilt each hour
Would strike your conscious soul with terrors.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: No more, this boys words trouble me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: If none of these move, let the example
Of that contempt is thrown on runagates
Even by these Turks themselves, at least move you
To fly this slavery.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Most worthy sir, now I dare call you brother,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Too fair a name to cloak so great a foe,
This instant makes a trial of your virtue,
Think on Ulysses' constancy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Why are you mute sir?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I am not well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Alas! how can he, being so near to hell?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Are you so weak to have a boys words sway you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You have not mine, think 'tis heaven's hand doth stay you

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Have you no other but my sister sir,
To make a stale off, did you not vow?

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Whate'er , I do recant it, I am now
Myself, her looks enchanted me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Against a man's own soul, no oath can tie.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: This thy disgrace revenged shall speak in blood.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Where is my betrothed husband? All's ready.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: To publish infamy to thee and us?
The weathercock is turned, this boys breath did it ▪

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Again turned?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You cast your eyes too much upon the flame
Proves your destruction.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Ungentle boy, dost thou requite me thus?
How canst thou blushless view me, have my tears
Procured me naught but scorn?

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Forgiveness Voada: turn back thy comet-eyes,
Plagues, devils, poverty, may all ills fall
man e'er was subject to, I will enjoy thee.
Force hence, I say, this boy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: As I from hence, so thou art thrust from joy, eternal joys.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: The mufti's here: you know the custom sir,
Some trivial ceremonies, they'll be soon o'er,
They once performed you're ne'er unhappy more.
Besides, the captainship of our strong castle
Shall be my sister's portion, here's the key.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Do not delay them then.

div.stage: Enter the slaves bound, going to the port.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: They are come sir.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: What mean these slaves, their sights like basilisks
Foretells my ruin: 'sheart make this way.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, do not shun our sight, hear us but now,
We'll forgive all our wrongs, with patience row
At the unwieldy oar: we will forget
That we were sold by you, and think we set
Our bodies 'gainst your soul, the dearest purchase
Of your redeemer, that we regained you so,
Leave but this path damnation guides you to.

sp.speaker: 2. Son.
sp.l: Our blood, our father's blood, all is forgiven,
The bond of all thy sins is cancelled,
Keep but thy self from this.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let us redeem our country's shame by thee,
We willing will endure our slavery.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: The words do rip my heart up: ha?

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: Why stand you in this dilemma: are you deprived
Of sense and being?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Thou tellst me true: with what brain can I think
Heaven would be glad of such a friend as I am.
A pirate, murderer? let those can hope a pardon care
To atone with heaven, I cannot, I despair.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will you yet hear me? yet heaven hath mercy.

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.l: And hell damnation: on, zounds on I say,
The way that leads to love is no black way.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But thou wilt find it black: no hell I see's so low
Which lust and woman cannot lead us to.
Might be compared to his, who adjudged to death
By his heads loss, should crave (Stead of one stroke)
To die a lingering torment on the rack.
Even such would be your life, whose guilt each hour
Would strike your conscious soul with terrors.

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.l: No more, this boys words trouble me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: If none of these move, let the example
Of that contempt is thrown on runagates
〈◊〉 by these Turks themselves, at least move you
To 〈◊〉 this slavery.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Most worthy sir, now I dare call you brother,

sp.speaker: Fr●n
sp.l: Too fair a name to cloak so great a foe,
This instant makes a trial of your virtue,
Think on Ulysses' constancy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Why are you mute sir?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I am not well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Alas! how can he, being so near to hell?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Are you so weak to have a boys words sway you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You have not mine, think 'tis heaven's hand doth stay you

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: Have you no other but my sister sir,
To make a stale off, did you not vow?

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Whate'er , I do recant it, I am now
Myself, her looks in chanted me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Against a man's own soul, no oath can tie.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: This thy disgrace revenged shall speak in blood.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Where is my betrothed husband? All's ready.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: To publish infamy to thee and us?
The weathercock is turned, this boys breath did it.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Again turned?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You cast your eyes too much upon the flame
Proves your destruction.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Ungentle boy, dost thou requite me thus?
How canst thou blushless view me, have my tears
Procured me naught but scorn?

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Forgiveness Voada: turn back thy comet-eyes,
Plagues, devils, poverty, may all ills fall
man e'er was subject to, I will enjoy thee.
Force hence, I say, this boy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: As I from hence, so thou art thrust from joy, eternal joys.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: The mufti's here: you know the custom sir,
Some trivial ceremonies, they'll be soon o'er,
They once performed you're ne'er unhappy more.
Besides, the captainship of our strong castle
Shall be my sister's portion, here's the key.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Do not delay them then.

div.stage: Enter the slaves bound, going to the port.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: They are come sir.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: What mean these slaves, their sights like basilisks
Foretells my ruin: 'sheart make this way.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, do not shun our sight, hear us but now,
We'll forgive all our wrongs, with patience row
At the unwieldy oar: we will forget
That we were sold by you, and think we set
Our bodies 'gainst your soul, the dearest purchase
Of your redeemer, that we regained you so,
Leave but this path damnation guides you to.

sp.speaker: 2. Son.
sp.l: Our blood, our father's blood, all is forgiven,
The bond of all thy sins is cancelled,
Keep but thy self from this.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let us redeem our country's shame by thee,
We willing will endure our slavery.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: The words do rip my heart up: ha?

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: Why stand you in this dilemma: are you deprived
Of sense and being?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Thou tellst me true: with what brain can I think
Heaven would be glad of such a friend as I am.
A pirate, murderer? let those can hope a pardon care
To atone with heaven, I cannot, I despair.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will you yet hear me? yet heaven hath mercy.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: And hell damnation: on, zounds on I say,
The way that leads to love is no black way.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But thou wilt find it black: no hell I see's so low
Which lust and woman cannot lead us to.

div.stage: The dumb show, with chorus of Ward turning Turk.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Here could I wish our period, or that our pen
Might speak the fictions, not the acts of men.
The deeds we have presented hitherto, are white
Compared unto those black ones we must write:
For now no more at men, but giantlike
The face of heaven itself, he dares to strike:
And with a blushless front he dares to do,
What we are dumb to think, much more to show:
Yet what may fall beyond uncertain guess
Your better savours bind us to express.

div.stage: Enter two bearing halfmoons, one with a Mahomet's head following. After them the muffty, or chief priest ▪ two meaner priests bearing his train. The mufti seated, a confused noise of music, with a shout. Enter two Turks, one bearing a turban with a half-moon in it, the other a robe, a sword: a third with a globe in one hand, an arrow in the other: two knights follow. After them Ward on an ass, in his Christian habit, bareheaded. The two knights, with low reverence, ascend, whisper the muffty in the ear, draw their swords, and pull him off the ass. He laid on his belly, the tables (By two inferior priests) offered him, he lifts his hand up, subscribes, is brought to his seat by the muffty, who puts on his turban and robe, girds his sword: then swears him on the Mahomet's head, ungirts his sword, offers him a cup of wine by the hands of a christian: he spurns at him, and throws away the caps, is mounted on the ass, who is richly clad, and with a shout

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: The accursed priests of Mahomet being set;
Two knights present the wretch, who finds no let
To his perdition: to whom nor shame, nor fear
Give any curse. Dismounted from that steed
Did best befit the rider: they then read
the laws of their damned prophet: he subscribes,
Enrolls his name into their pagan tribes.
Now wears the habit of a freeborn Turk,
His sword excepted, which lest they should work
Just villany to their seducers, is denied
Unto all runagates, unless employed
In wars 'gainst Christians. Last, o be he last
For swears his name! with what, we blush to tell,
But 'tis no wonder, blacks the way to hell,
Who though he seem yet happy, his success
Shows he exchanged with it, and wretchedness.
Give patience to our scene, which hereto tends,
To show the world, black deeds will have black ends.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Ward turned Turk? it is not possible.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: I saw him Turk to the circumcision.
Marry therein I heard he played the Jew with 'em,
Made 'em come to the cutting off an ape's tail.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: I see the hand of heaven prevented mine,
Death was too fair a guerdon for him. But to the present,
Deserving sir, I now am to conjure you
By all the offices of friendship past,
By what my future love, and means may stead you,
To vow performance of one small request.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Whate'er it be I'll be as just to you
As heaven to truth: by all that Ward denied,
I vow me yours.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I accept your faith: know then that I am bound
Unto a desperate attempt, how it may succeed,
Heaven and fate only know. The circumstance
I do enjoin you further not to inquire.
What on your trust's imposed is the redeeming
Those two betrayed young men, whom ward did sell,
When to his barbarous cruelty they opposed,
And lost themselves, and state: their ransom's here,
As you prove just, from all mishaps rest clear,

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: And if I fail to accomplish your desires,
All my sins haunt me, when my breath expires.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: I am most confident, best sir adieu,
If Dansiker do live, he lives to you.
Hast laid the train to my directions?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: It is done to the undoing of 'em all,
Time calls aboard which spends not half an hour
Before our train do take it rests to be determined
What ships we fire, which bear along with us.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Danvils makes with us, all the rest give fire to,
Sares ship except, to him we are engaged,
Nor will we prove ungrateful, are all things ready,

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: To your own wishes.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Aboard then instantly, Tunis farewell,
Dansiker bids all pirates now adieu.
He'll show you, what you might do, were you true

div.stage: Enter Agar above in the window

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: How dull a pace keeps time to lovers eyes,
And yet to me how swift the night's black horse,
Makes way to raise the morn, whose least of light
Takes all my hopes from me and damps me quite,
Eleven and yet not come, he was not capable
Of my quaint stratagem, or being possessed
Of what he wanted, gold, contemns my love,
It is no other Agar, he loathes thee,
Man's curse is, things forbid, still to pursue
What's freely offered not to hold worth their view,
Ha● unless my credulous ears deceive me,
There one make towards my window,

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p:
The coast is clear, bawd night I do salute thee thou that dost wink at all faults, that hugst'st so many sins in thy black bosom, the sun grows pale to view them, to thee damnation's nurse I make my prayer, conjure thee by all my lustful embraces thou hast been witness to, by all the cuckolds thou hast made 'twixt morn and twilight to add one to the number, but one thou black eyed negro, never did woman make such shift to dub her husband, though many
thou dost know have made most bare ones, o let this instrument that hath so many freed from the hell of usurers, and from the jaws of their fear, bandogs, hath paid so manies debts relieve my wants, I'll never blame thee, fortune henceforth if I lack, put thyself but this once on my my back, no false light in the window, no bawdy landmark, no handkerchief to waft me, I'll venture it, Agar, my lovely Agar.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: It's he who in this dead of night calls on my name.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Thy friend, thy understanding friend, with the ladder of ropes, here make them sure above, leave me to the lower parts.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: I hope you mean no wrong sir to me.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: I'll do thee as much right as can be done to one of thy sex, hast made it fast?
