sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: You may adventure sir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: He that will not adventure for such a piece of flesh, were worthy to feed upon dumplings all days on's life, nay I will venture, thou warden of the horned livery, omnipotent Vulcan, now set my shafts but right,
sp.l: I'll make one freeman more ere it be light.

sp.speaker: 1. Sailor
sp.p: There's no remedy, that which makes weighting-women punks, and captains panders, that causeth decayed gentlemen become solicitors, and bankrupt citizens sergeants, that makes us thieves, necessity, that which hath no law on's side.

sp.speaker: 2. Sailor
sp.p: We shall have as little conscience anon in robbery.

sp.speaker: 1. Sailor
sp.p: Ay, should we rob hospitals, our betters have made that a monopoly, but to steal from a rich Jew it is no more sin than to unload a weary ass.

sp.speaker: 2. Sailor
sp.p: By hook or crook you will have it.

sp.speaker: 1. Sailor
sp.p: We were bred in a country that had the charity to whip begging out of us, when we were young, and for starving, manhood denies it, you know what must necessarily follow.

sp.speaker: 2. Sailor
sp.p: Nay make your conclusion.

sp.speaker: 1. Sailor
sp.p:
Press her in a dumb show, hereabouts should be
the house, great windows and a little wicket, noble manlike, what's here a ladder of ropes, 'sfoot we are prevented, s. Nicolas clerks are stepped up before us.

sp.speaker: 2. Sailor
sp.p: Were they ten justices clerks we would share with 'em.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor
sp.p: There masters would prevent us for that, yet since our case is desperate, we will put in with 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Sailor
sp.p: Softly for waking the maids.

sp.speaker: 1. Sailor
sp.p: S'hart, thou art the son of a lapland-witch sure, this is the maid's chamber, one of them is in a dream, she fetcheth her wind short I am sure

sp.speaker: 2 sailor
sp.p: How long thou art poking at it, what is't man?

sp.speaker: 1. Sailor
sp.p: Some light commodity or other.

sp.speaker: 2. Sailor
sp.p: A woman's lower part, it is altogether in fashion for them to be light about the bum indeed.

sp.speaker: 1. Sailor
sp.p: I have the male part to't, the doublet, your women will have it ever in request to have the man's part uppermost.

sp.speaker: 2. Sailor
sp.p: S'hart, a French slop, these are none of the Jews trousers, and they should be no gallants, for he hath money in his purse.

sp.speaker: 1. Sailor
sp.p: I marry fir, this fellow had good ware about him indeed, upon my life we are little better than bawds, get money by others venery, this Jew is a

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: 2. Sailor
sp.p: Water, water, water

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Fire, fire, fire, the slaves lie on straw-beds, and yet this cry will take no hold on 'em, fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Flames and brimstone, I am in hell, zounds my breeches, the ladder, this Jew hath found us out and fired the house.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Dear sir contain yourself.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: A plague on venery, a hot end comes on't still, is the window high enough that I may break my neck, die any death rather than be roasted?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Here's a vault leads to the common shower, it being low-water the sheets shall let you down to your escape.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Those sheets have brought me low enough already. Within fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Flames stop thy throat.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Dear sir adventure it and save your life.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Were it to hell I must,
A plague on whores say, whose vast desires
Begins in watery tears and end in fires.

div.stage: Enter Rabshake at one door, and Jew at another.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: An ocean overwhelm thee, where is the fire slave?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: At the Jews house, Benwash his house, your house sir:

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: My bags, my obligations, my wife Agar I say, I shall run mad, I will scale the windows, burn for company, my money and myself will go together, what's here a ladder of ropes, gallops breeches, burn on, burn on, singe all the world, consume it with thy flames, thou best of elements, burn on I say.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: As you are men on this side help to save our goods.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: As you are ministers of Lucifer let it burn on, it's mine own house, come but on my ground I'll have my action for't.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: He is distracted, help as you are men.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Dogs, villains, thieves, down with him that lays a hand a to't, be just you powers of heaven, and throw thy wild fire down upon the heads of these adulterers, room, room, room, I have it, I have it, room, room, room.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: The Jew is mad indeed, his loss distracts him, speak gentle friend, doth the fire slack.

sp.speaker: Rub.
sp.p: The house is saved, but all the ships in the harbour unquenchable do burn.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: The ships in the harbour.

sp.speaker: Rub.
sp.l: Yours only excepted.

sp.speaker: Frans.
sp.l: My thoughts now have their ends,

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Do not thou grieve boy, know I love thee
Thy maintenance shall express it, I have friends
And jewels left for thee, but I hate thee more
Than all thy wealth made me love thee before

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: False woman, thou shalt not shake me off thus
were all the impudence of thy whole sex,
All there blushless impieties confined in thee
I'll move thy flinty heart to sense and shame,
I will thou sorceress: now I do see too late
There is a hand o'errules our will and fate.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: This shows the greatest plague heaven keeps ●in store falls, when a man is linked unto a whore.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: I have it, I have it, here, here, nay come on, you have come off I am sure, here's evidence looks pale to think but on't, you do not know the tenant to this cottage, he was an upright dealer, he paid me to a hair, come forward and be hanged, I shall advance you in a rope's name, you have made no cuckold of me. I made myself one, pandered my own horns, now sirrah, you that go to't by art, put your cases one in the neck of another, your remembering in re what think you of this case.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I think the serpent crept into a narrow hole, and left his case behind him.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Then I am a cornuto.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: This make's the naked truth appear so.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: The best is, the crest is mine own, I paid well for't.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Dear husband pardon me, I will confess,

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: What wilt thou confess? that thou hast made a mere ass of me, to pay thy journeyman wages before hand.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: It should seem he laboured hard to earn it, he could keep no clothes about him.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: This slave doth not think I'll cut his throat for this, you have watched nearly sirrah, you have.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Unless I should have been their bawd, I could watch no nearer, methinks she hath done you a great pleasure, rid you of your disease, jealousy, now you need fear no more, you are in possession on't, your doubts are at an end.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p:
Good, very good, my doubts are at end, but I shall hang you in suspense for this: you Manticora that plump upon raw flesh, here set your hand to this letter, that I may draw your captain on again upon the breach, I'll blow you
up else, why move you not, I am sure you laid your hand to the business when time was.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, I know my life is forfeit
To your just anger, nor will I be the means
To shed more blood, mine shall suffice alone,
Since only one is wronged punish but one.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: She loves him still, I am a cuckold
He has outgone me, do you hear; subscribe
Move me no further.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: The worst can be but death, I will not.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: I tell thee I'll for give thee, give my revenge
Scope but at him, thou art free.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Swear it by Abraham's dust, the ashes of our forefathers.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.l: Dust and ashes it's but a frail oath.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: By that, and all that ties a virtuous mind,
I vow and swear by written writ.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.l: You'll swear as much to forgive me I hope to sir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Why, thou shalt be the messenger, nay the actor
In my just vengeance.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.l: The hangman you mean sir, I am expert at it.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Francisco, what news man?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The worst your ears can hear, our ships

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: They are untouched, of all they are only safe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You dazzle your own eyes, that villain Dansiker
Hath grappled them and fled.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Whirlwinds pursue him, heaven, seas, earth, all at once
Join to his confusion, now I do see too late
There is a hand o'errules our will and fate.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: I shall then take your promise, your brother being redeemed, this night I shall enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: This diamond binds me to't, by this I swear.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: 'Tis thine I will bestow it on thee, to tie thy faith
Thou hast his ransom.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: 'Tis here.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: About it then, now fortune equal prove
I am happy, yet her lust redeems my love.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Yet see, midst all my miseries I have a friend,
My constant loyal Voada, could what we enjoy
Make a man happy, I am not miserable.
Thou comest to comfort me, I know thou dost.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: This fellow raves sure: do you know to whom you speak?

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Put not a further trial on me, thou best of women:
Know if this arm were bared all other means
From hearts of Christians, it should dig thee food.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: We know you are a bloody murderer, and are repaid
By our just prophet, that hates false runagates.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: How couldst thou malice man so much, heaven,
As to create a woman?
Thou hast forgotten me sure: o look on him
That hath denied his faith, sold all his hopes
To purchase thee his bride.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: To match with beggary: know I contemn thee
As a most abject slave, and hate thee more
Than all thy wealth could make me love before.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What mean you sir? could you expect a good,
A happiness from hell? she is a whore.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Thou liest: this arm shall make it good,
My soul for her I lost, and now my blood.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Your passion doth transport you, here comes her pander,
One that knows all her secrets: examine him,
If she stand clear, let my life answer it.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: I'll put you to the test.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I have had a hot night of this, nothing but fire in my mouth two hours together: marry the old Jew my master I hear hath stumbled on a cooler. I thought this captain would be coming so long on upon the breach he would break his neck at the last. This venery is a tempting dish, some ne'er lin licking at it till they burn their lips. Well, I must go comfort up old Benwash, he's heavy upon his wife's lightness.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.p: You Jew, a word with you?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
You Turk, I have nothing to say to you: ha, ha, ha,
poor fellow, how he looks since Mahomet had the handling of him? he hath had a sore night at whose that knocks at the backdoor? Cry you mercy, I thought you were an Italian captain.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.p: Zounds, leave your circumlocutions, I'll send your head to your heels else.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You parcel haud, all usher, answer directly who 'tis bears a way the prize in your mistress's race, or I'll spoil your footing, cut you off by the hams.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Alas sir!

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Speak, who are her suitors?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Voadi's suitors? o sir, a barber sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'll make you have need of a surgeon ere I have done with you. How do you know he is a barber?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: He smells strong of rose-water, and he hath never money in his purse but on saturday-nights.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: What other suitor, slave?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: another sweet youth too, I take it a comfit-maker; and it seems hath rotten teeth, for he dares not come in sight so long as the barber's in the way.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: This dog deludes us, I'll tear thy throat out villain, unless thou instantly name him she loves.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Her page sir, the little christian, the good faced captain gave her, Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: My slave, the French ship-boy?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I saw him leave her now. How dost thou know she loves him?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: She makes him sing bawdy songs to her, looks fortunes in his fist, and babies in his eyes, makes dialogues betwixt him, her little dog, and herself: lies upon her back, puts his hand in her hand, and wrings it till the tears come again.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.p: Insatiate monster, could her swollen blood reach such a height none but my page must suit her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Contain yourself a while, this slave can speak one of her dialogues.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: It is my practice sir: you shall stand for the lady, you for her dog, and I the page: you and that dog looking one upon another, the page presents himself.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.l: The best is behind sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Jew, slave, dog.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: The horned devil follow him. A skippers boy?
The shame of woman? rather than be baffled thus
I will betray this town, blow up the castle:
Francisco, do but second me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: First repossess yourself of your strong hold,
I fear some treachery: the governor
With all the janissaries of the town
I met in their way thither.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Blast them ye powers first. The governor
Make towards the castle? I am betrayed, away,
I see that heaven forgets not though I delay.
Thrust out by janissaries?

sp.speaker: Ianisa.
sp.l: Pack hence false runagate,
Slave, beggar.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Disgracious vassals, what mountain covers me?
Wink, wink, thou daystar, hide my guilty shame,
Make me as if I ne'er had been, whose name
Succeeding times will curse: should I confess my sin,
There's not an ear that can with pity hear
A man so wicked miserable: should I bear up,
Outlook my crimes, I want means to support me.
To die I dare not, the jaws of hell do yawn
To swallow me: live I cannot ▪ famine threats,
And that the worst of poverty, contempt and scorn.
Never on man fate cast so black a frown,
Up I am denied to fly, unpitied down.
Rest restless soul on this accursed soil,
And teach the world into how sad a toil
Ambition and swift riot run, when mean content
Sits low, yet happy: and when their day is spent
All that they get is labour and unrest,
A hateful grave, and worst, a troubled breast.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Where shall I find this most unfortunate wretch?
There is a part in him called man, which we should pity
how ere his merit stands, nor will I leave him,
Though he hath left himself. See where he lies
Best suiting with his fortunes, could we our fate foreknow
Men were as gods, nor need we have lain so low.
How fare you brother? why with so sad an eye
Do you behold me, that in your miseries
Bear equal part?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Can there remain a soul that will vouchsafe
Compassion on me? thou dost but flatter,
Or hast forgotten, I have lost all, and poverty
When no ill else will do't, makes all friends fly.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Were you entitled to no other guilt,
How willing for you should my blood be spilt?
Here sir, accept this poor relief
Bootless alas distress recounts those errors
To think what might have been cures, not the terrors
Of present suffering.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: True, true, Francisco, could I redeem the time,
The world should speak my penitence.
Could I call back but one seven years,
Though all my life were servile after,
Were my soul but free
From innocent blood, and fearful blasphemy,
On the condition I might live an age
Tortured upon a wheel.
I tell thee friend,
Were I this city's viceroy, I would give
My crown, despoil myself of all, only to live
One month with that content this soul did know
When a poor fisherman possessed it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You are too low dejected.
Men that with sufferance their wrongs do bear
Are held but weak, and states more oft for fear
Then love unto the right, redress men's ills.
Who stoutly down his enemies, malice kills,
Who basely wounds himself.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: No less than truth, I have been too low indeed
each one the yielding grass doth dare to tread
That flies resisting thorns, false Voada,
Thy lamb is turned a lion, I feel revenge
Give a new life to me, I'll only stay
Till I have spoke thy brother, I think he'll blush
To hear thy shame, tell thee thou hast not played
A woman's part with me, suppose the worse
That he turn villain to, he had better curse
His grand sirs ashes, if once more I fall in
I'll be unparalleled at least for sin.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Stay see the strumpet's love, Fidelio,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Captain, you are the man I seek, I have a suit to you,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Concerning Voada, is't not?

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Concerning her that hates you for my sake
Neglects your merit, this night gives full revenge
To all her injuries.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Repeat that happy word again, I am wholly thine.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Know her vassaliat lust hath long pursued,
And with such violence attempted me,
That with my oaths this night to sate her heat
I hardly have delayed her.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: What's this to my revenge?

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: It follow's, give me but way
Through your castle there's a Hollander
This evening makes from hence
That gives them passage.
I have tied him to't

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Thou art for ever free, the hour name,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: I'll speak your worth yet, in spite of fame
About three, watch the word Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Avoid suspicion and till then be gone.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Nay then my joys do flow,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Whether tends this? what passage, come you for him?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: To heaven I once more must exact
Thy trust and diligence.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Speak it.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Make instantly to Voada, tell her
this night a skipper doth attend to steal aboard
Her love Fidelio, give her the hour and place
Wish her to pistol him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Wouldst have her kill her to.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Ay, and run made for't, meanwhile I'll walk the streets I shall meet some will know me to whom I will relate my wrongs, wilt do't Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My soul to gauge.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: This comfort then in spite of hell I'll have,

sp.speaker: Vvard
sp.l: Went not unrevenged unto his grave.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: How black a path unbounded riot treads,
Your gentler eyes have viewed. Our scene now leads
To give him rest, that from his ills had learned
To know his misery, and at least had earned
This lesson from the extremes, that others past
No course that violent is, secure can last.
This clue doth wind him back, and Dansiker,
The wealth of Tunis, now is become there fear,
Strives to redeem his infamy and with success,
Makes through their bowels to his happiness.
No sooner he arrives in France, but his sad ears
Instead of welcomes entertain new fears,
The aged oak that atlas-like sustained,
The weight of France, that with his blood regained
Her wasted body, like the pelican
By one that from his life took breath is slain,
This fatal blow, astonisheth the hopes
Of Dansiker, and his, to make return,
Impossible those fires yet fresh do burn,
Would threaten them with utmost tortures here
To make abode, they find themselves beset
With many they by their spoil made foes, yet
Twixt two extremes they chose the better part
Take land and to the governor present
themselves and fortunes, show their act, intent
And penitence, their promised pardon, what befell
This show presents, which words deny to tell.

div.stage: Enter governor in state, takes his seat, Dansiker and his followers with ropes about their necks, their weapons with the points towards them, deliver their petition, the governor reads and salutes them, put up their swords, suddenly rush in divers like merchants with followers, seem to threaten the governor, who defends Dansiker, labours betwixt them, seem pacified, and Dansiker swears by his sword, offer to go out to meet his wife and child, they persuade, he delivers them to the governor's trust. Omnes exeunt.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Twixt hope and dread, as suited former merit,
The governor receives them gives new spirit
Unto their drooping hopes, when with the name
Of Dansikers arrival, swift winged fame
Brings in the oppressed merchants, whose spoil
Had fed his hungry sword, and with their toil
Made rich his rapines, these crave law, his life
The opposing governor almost ends the strife,
With his own blood, informs them, the King's death
Stood only bar to his safety, that his breath
Would recompense all former injuries,
To approve it gives them notice of the prize
Brought from Tunis, and more to assuage their ire
Dansiker dare, what act they can desire
Man to accomplish, to redeem his peace
And their great losses, all their furies cease.
And with one voice demand Benwash the Jew
As his just ransom, they need no more renew,
This their request, by oath themselves they tie.
To bring him prisoner, or in the action die.
No motives from his wife or child dissuade,
This his resolve, suppose he now hath made
His back return and in some apt disguise
attends success unto his enterprise
His end and strange prevention, briefly show
Designs are men's, their sway the gods do owe.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: This is the place a cold blood thwarts my heart,
My fleeting soul in her disturbed passion
Proclaims some ill near, let me suppose the worst
Aliziaes dead, false tongue how durst thou name
So great a mischief? alas this bracelet speaks it,
This which I tied unto her ivory wrist
The witness of those vows confirmed us one,
The news of my captivity took all her hopes
And life away, and dying she bequeathed
This loyal gift again, with my sad ransom.
'T may be this youth may be Alizia
Herself a prisoner, yet she's to virtuous
To outlive her honour and her chastity,
Which her captivity must needs endanger:
I hear his footsteps.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: We are not far off from the place, softly, softly.
The night is dark and friendly to mine ends.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Fidelio, Fidelio,

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: 'Tis he would rob me of Fidelio,

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Fidelio I say young Raymond here

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Shoot.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: So I am slain.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Thus dost thou bear Fidelio back again,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O false, false Alizia thy watchwords as thyself
Deceiving, didst think my slavery
Was not an ill sufficient, but my blood
Must pay thy falsehood tribute, or couldst not wish
So great a plague to me, that I should hear
Thou wert turned prostitute, ungentle cruel woman,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: 'Tis not the boy sure, his voice, his passion
Speaks him another, more projects yet, I hear some foot stir.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: How fearful is the night, heaven's angry sure,
And having drawn the day up, chid her thus
For giving light to men's impieties.
'Tis much about the hour of my appoint,
What sad groan wounds my ears, Fidelio,
Raymond, friend Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Or rather Infidelio, whate'er thou art
Thou needst not doubt thy task, thou hast made me sure,
Or if thou doubts it, here discharge one bullet more.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: 'Tis not his voice, thou liest false thoughts, Raymond, Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: My name is Raymond, that Fidelio unjustly murdered.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: No marvel though thou thunderest heaven;
And darts thy flashes down, o! why is not
This world a universal fire? what one good
Keeps back thy flames?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O speak! what art thou? whose sad speech
Makes death stay yet to hear thee.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: My friend, my Raymond by my means murdered
I have lived too long, too long.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O speak! what art thou whose sad accents force
Pale death to stay and hear thee.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Alas I am nothing, nothing.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: As thou hast hope in heaven tell me thy name,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: I will, my name's Alizia, thy constant loyal, loyal friend, that in her passage unto thee will not be long

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O save thy life.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Wish me not so much ill, I love thee better.
Miracle of thy sex, o let me embrace thee yet.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Here, here, fly hence vain breath,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: No other good is known to me but death, moritur

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Francisco thou'rt a villain, forgiveness Voada,
The words of these two innocents with purple eyes
Dart terror through me, Fidelio turned a woman.
Within follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Voad
sp.l: I will rather give an ear to the black shrieks
Of mandrakes, thou knewest I loved him
and that hath forc● his wound, at sight whereof
Methinks reflecting heaven should spread itself
In a deep crimson veil, blush to have created
A wretch so monstrous, but my revenge sleeps, know boy
I will repay thy death, slave I will famish thee,
And when thy fainting eyelids 'gin to crack,
My satisfied lust, by him most hates thee,
Shall be thy object.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: You wrong me to suppose I should be guilty
Of such an impious deed.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Doth not thy blood stained poniard speak it
With which thy accursed arm did force his breast
His too too gentle breast.

sp.speaker: W●rd.
sp.l: Thyself be witness.

div.stage: Stabs at him, he beats it back, and wounds her.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: That I am revenge on thee, murder, murder, the slave will murder me.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: What mean you wife?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: As you are men make rescue of me.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I am betrayed, outgone by a she devil.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: He hath not only slain his innocent page,
But thus assailed my life, lay hands on him
Dear countrymen revenge my wrongs, my blood
On this false runagate, I faint, I faint.
Convey me to a chirurgeon, make him safe.

sp.speaker: 1. Offi
sp.p: In the governor's name I do command you give your weapons up.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: S'hart gentlemen, you know Francisco killed him, I'll make it good.

sp.speaker: 2. Offi.
sp.p: We have nothing to charge you with about your page it is the wounding your wife with an unlawful weapon.

sp.speaker: 1. Offi.
sp.p: You have most unmanly thrust in a woman.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Honest friends, Turks, and officers, if ever I laid hands on her, may I never see light more.

sp.speaker: 1. Offi.
sp.p: We'll take a reasonable order for that, you ne'er laid hands on her, out impudence away to the dungeon with him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: S'hart carry me to the governor that I may have justice first.

sp.speaker: 2. Offi.
sp.p:
The fellow raves, he thinks men in office have nothing to do but to give him justice, you must first be punished
and then talk of justice when you have cause.

sp.speaker: 1. Offic.
sp.p: Away with him, he shall know what 'tis to marry into a great tribe, an honourable tribe: you use a great woman as if she were your wife, you're a base fellow indeed. You a courtier?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Nay, than I see my end draws, I shall rave,
Run mad: have you er'a bedlam, that I may not famish
But show tricks to get meat with, or rail against the state:
And when I have eased my gall a month or two
Come out again. Zounds let me beat hemp,
Do any thing rather than famish: that death
She hath vowed me, and I'll prevent it: allow me
But every week a christian, I am content
To feed upon raw flesh, if't be but once a month
A Britain, I'll be content with him.

sp.speaker: 2. Offic.
sp.l: Nay then you are mad indeed, away with him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: As you are true Turks, I will put you in sureties,
I know the devil will provide me bale,
Rather than lose my employment: as you are pitiful Turks.

sp.speaker: 1. Offic.
sp.l: Nay then we shall be troubled with you.

sp.speaker: Vvard.
sp.l: Plagues, pestilences, all fall upon my head
Rather than by a whore be famished.
I do conjure you.

div.head: Scoena ultima.
div.stage: Enter Benwash, Rabshake, at several doors.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Rabshake?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Is this child of Adam coming yet? he that will eat of the forbidden fruit though he lose paradise fort, is he coming.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: As fast as his legs will bear him, considering the use he means to put them to. I have provided a caudle to comfort him with.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
That's my dear precious villain, how sweet art thou
revenge? the thought of thee turns all my blood to air.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And your horns too sir?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: All light rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: They were begot light, but methinks they should be heavy in the wearing.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I will make them abortives man, smother them in the womb.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Though you lop the branches, you will preserve the tree to bear more fruit, I hope, your wife sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: She shall down too, I will let her blood in a new vein she shall turn up the white of the eye, and die the death of a sinner.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: How will you dispense with your oaths sir?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Tush, by equivocation man, I will not hurt her, but thou shalt by equivocation, behind the arras, my dear rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: That word (By equivocation) lies on my stomach, I would be loath it should make me cast up my gall, I would not have my throat cut by equivocation.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: The game is roused, take thy stand and strike rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Strike you sir? you are the keeper, and have the fees in possession, I have no money upon this equivocation.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: So the hour of my redemption is at hand, for man's worst hell, a whore.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: You put me to a sweet purgation the other night, 'twas well fear took away some of my senses, I had smelled for't else.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: You saw the necessity of it sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: You may call it necessity. I thought of the day of judgement, and that was more than ever I did in my life before: what with the fire above, and the ram-headed devil your husband below, I imagined damnation could not be far off.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Good, excellent good.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
And whither is that golden calf of Horeb, that Jew of the the tribe of Israel gone, that it is jubilee with you
now, all open?

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: He is rid to the Goletto about taking in a commodity.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: And in the mean time thou wilt utter one at home, I am thy merchant wench, and will deal with thee by wholesale.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Rather by retail sir, retail.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Where is your Pim Rabshake, taking a nap at the stair foot, committing sin in conceit, whilst we are at it in action? hath he the two qualities of an usher, a good ear, and to endure cold of his feet? have you given him instructions?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I see how it did work, I feel it.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: He'll make the old Jew believe I was his wife's bawd.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: The slave was born pander, his mother was a midwife, and then he must needs be bawd to set his mother's trade a-work.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: You will groan for this anon sir.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: I pray you sir sit down, a small banquet sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Provocatives and whetters on? one liquorous thing draws out another. Who will not swear venery is a sweet sin now? Bacchus and Venus, two gods, the devil is far enough off then.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: You are deceived sir, he is at your elbow.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Is Dunne in the mire? for old acquaintance' sake we'll drag you out sir: you are in travel, I am the son of a midwife, I'll help to deliver you.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: It cannot be, I am in a dream.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: A good belief doth well; were I in your case, I should be passed dreaming: but I'll cast you in a slumber sir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: You must be at your sweet meats: cannot mutton serve your turn, but you must have sauce to it?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: This whore hath betrayed me: now she hath wrung what she can out of me, she hangs me up for a dried neats-tongue. She is an insatiate whore sir, hath enticed me by the pander your man: I was chaste before I knew her sir.

sp.speaker: Rabsh.
sp.p:
Believe him not sir, he is a mere goat, look on
his beard else.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: You may see by his hair he is a man of hot liver; he came over me with such violence I had not the heart to resist him.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: I believe you wife, I believe you, and thou shalt justify it to his teeth before the greatest devil in hell. Rabshake give her a mittimus, strangle her.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Have you forgotten your oaths sir?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: I sware as I was a Turk, and I will cut your throat as I am a Jew.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Villain, keep off, I say.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: You should have said so when time was mistress.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Thou betrayest thyself slave, makest way to thine own destruction.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Stop her throat, I say, give no ear to her.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: I do confess my sin, I have wrongfully betrayed thee.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: I find myself in bonds for't lady, it is some comfort yet, that I die not unrevenged.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Thou speakest charitably. Is she gone? is her lust satisfied now?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Do a woman to death, and she will be satisfied, nothing else will.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Now for you m. Gallop: you gave it me with tilting, and I will return your courtesy.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Save my life sir, and I will be your slave, sell myself in open market, brand me.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: That were lex talion indeed, one mark for another: but it will not serve the turn. Have at you.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, how the ox gores him.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath villains, treacherous villains, the plague, pox.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: He died a true lecher, with the pox in his mouth. Why this was valiantly done sir, in single opposition.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Why now my brow begins to smooth. How likest this tragedy, rabshake?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Rarely, if it do not prove a tragedy to us sir, it's but a comedy hitherto: the setting off is all.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p:
Tush, the best is behind man: dost think I do not
bear a brain about me? Beware a politician, man: here, bind me, bind me, hard, hard.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I marry sir, I like this well, a man may trust you when your hands are tied behind you.

sp.speaker: Iow.
sp.p: I cannot choose but laugh to think how happy I am in my project: it will amaze thee when thou hearest it Rabshake, we shall so gull the innocent world, laugh at the silly world.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: If you gull me now, I'll give you leave to make mummy of me: what's next sir?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Here, take this dagger, stab me an inch into the breast and arm.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Do you call this gulling of the world?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: I cannot but laugh at the gentleman's lecherous voyage to Lucifer: there, there. Now Rabshake let me bind thee.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: How? bind me?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Thou art not capable of the mystery, thou art shallow Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I do not desire to wade deeper in I thank you sir, I am no politician, bear no brain about me sir; yet I can dive into a knave's pockets as well as any man, your worship knows.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: What dost thou mean by this?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: To rob you as I am a Turk, and cut your throat as I am a Jew, you have forgotten your equivocation; I'll chop logic with you. Come, your rings, your chain: do you not laugh? have you not guled the world fairly?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Thou hast mistaken me: know thou art all my care.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And you would be rid of me, I conceive you sir, though I am no politician: I have seen the play of Pedringano sir, of Pedringano sir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Dear Rabshake, upon my knees I do entreat thee hear me.
For whom have I ta'en thought, outwatched the night
Out-toiled the day, but for my rabshake? what friend,
What kinsman, what heir had I but Rabshake?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Yes, you meant I should have been your heir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p:
Nay, thou shouldst have had all in possession, my purpose was to have lived a private life, done penance for my sins,
and given thee all.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: You would have parted with this chain, these rings and gold.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: They are thine own, on whom should I bestow them else?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And you have a trick to come off clear with this business.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: In spite of jealousy, without suspicion man: you being bound, your head thrust in this circle, as if tied up for starting, I had cried out thieves, murder, raised the street, transferred the act upon some stranger.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And I should have been your heir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Thou wrongest me to make question of't.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: If I should try him, it is beyond my compass if he outsail me: this chain and gold is mine.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: 'Sfoot myself too.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: For once I'll try you: here bind me, if you do outreach me, I'll ne'er trust Jew more.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Here, here: is thy head in?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: It is sir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Have I caught you? are you in the noose? you have seen the play of Pedringano sir, I'll play with you.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: 'sheart I am your slave sir, I did it to make your worship merry.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Tush, you are my heir, I'll hang you up a airing.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: As you are a man hear me sir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: You must have your chains, you shall be chained, I could even crack my sides with laughter. This will afford me mirth unto my dying day. The play of Pedringano? how the weasel hangs! Ha, ha, ha. Thieves, thieves: murder, murder. I shall betray myself with laughter. Were you caught Rynard? are you in the noose? Murder, murder, thief's murder.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Break open the doors, the voice speaks from this room.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: Inhuman deed! what hand could be so bloody?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Speak, who was the murderer?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Help me to a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: Run for a surgeon. Tell by what monster was this act (So full of horror) done?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Three strangers rushed in suddenly, we being at supper, all my servants forth, save honest rabshake: and having rifled us, did act this horrid murder.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Here is a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: The prophet Mahomet reveal the homicides.

div.stage: Enter governor, other officers, sare, Ferd. Alb. Dansiker disguised.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: What moves these outcries?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Behold a bloody murder, Benwash, his wife,
This captain, and his servant.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: My honest servant, honest Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Benwash murdered? he hath saved me a labour.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Is there any hope of life in him?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: His wounds are sleight, sir, only his faintheart makes them dangerous.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Take courage man. Speak, hast thou any knowledge of the murderers?

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: Only he says they are strangers, men of the sea.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Canst thou remember in what habit, what men of person and complexion they were?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: What means the slave to eye me so?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: That fellow in the stammel hose is one of them.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: On me? Villain, thou buyest my blood
At a dear rate. O thou immortal God
Who knowest my innocence! that for his former sins
Hast given up, Dansiker into the hands
Of these damned miscreants.

sp.speaker: Omn,
sp.l: Dansiker?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: I Dansiker, that would with all your deaths
Have cancelled his former infamy,
Left to the world a precedent of valour,
Writ in your sad confusions: but heaven is just,
Christians did fall by me, by slaves I must.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p:
Call forth the common hangman, by this time he hath
done his office on Francisco. Dansiker? unlooked for?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Hear me before I die, I do confess
Mine own hand did these murders. Dansiker
Hath justly done me vengeance.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: How's this? thou done these murders thyself, being bound and hurt? Thou ravest sure.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: I did them sir: the cause my wife proved false, untrue,
Bear witness, though I lived a Turk, I die a Jew.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Out dog, devil.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Unheard of monster! Cast his loathed carcase
Unto the common air. Never did day discover
Two such inhumane caitiffs, stretch out his arms,
You have your trains and fireworks, apply your torches
Unto his breast. We'll know what project now
Lead you unto this second venture.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: I will confess it willingly: it was to have conveyed
This Jew from hence, have made a massacre
Of the whole town, dashed out the miscreant brains ▪
Of your young infidels.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.l: And art not sorry, dog?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Yes dog, I am sorry, and confess my crimes
Prevented such a merit: I was not worthy
To do heaven so good a service.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Pull off his hateful flesh, dig out his heart
By piecemeal.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.l: Wilt thou turn Turk, and save thy soul yet?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Yes pagan, villain, I will. Forgiveness heaven,
Let my example move all pirates, robbers
To think how heavy thy revenging hand
Will sit upon them. I feel thy justice now,
Receive my soul, accept my intended vow.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: So, convey his hateful body to the same place,
The Jew doth lie unburied.
sp.stage: Enter at several doors Voad and Ward.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Justice, let me have justice, worthy governor.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Give her no ear, she is all woman dissimulation.
I am a Turk, and I do crave the law.

sp.speaker: Turk
sp.l: He hath wounded here a Turk, a lady, and
We crave sentence according to his merit.
He may receive the bastinado, pay a fine.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Pay a fine, what fine, from one that's famished,
For want of a poor asper, set me to sea again,
The tenth of what I'll bring you in, shall countervail
The revenue of the Indies.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: The slave is mad, we'll send you far enough,
Lady depose the for't, you shall have justice.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: By our great prophet Mahomet.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: You do me wrong, let me in private speak to her
Ere she betray my life, it is no less
Than your own law affords me.

sp.speaker: Turk
sp.l: The weakness of her body brooks it not.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: How say you Voada, can you afford him speech?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: I'll give his vain words hearing, though to much pain
O my deep wound let all remove from hence.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Had she a heart of brass i' de pierce it, leave us all.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Now sir your motion,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Wherein hath my desert strewed so much ill
To strain thy hate, to this a high beyond,
What we seem malice, I loved that face so well
To purchase it I exchanged my heaven with hell.
And to be barred what I so dear paid for,
Is't not a plague sufficient? but thy faith
Must now be sold, to be a vengeance greater,
To pay me ungrateful hire, canst thou behold
These eyes stroke inward, as ashamed to view
The fires which first betrayed them, this mind, body,
That doth contain a soul more black and dismal
Then is the raven night, these arms, that have so oft
Made to thee rules of love, now famished
For want of what thou surfeits on, canst without tears
Behold my miseries?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Prodigy of woman, dost laugh?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: This is true music, could I enjoy these tunes
Myself would be thy jailor.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Why then thy wound is not dangerous?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: A mere scratch, know that I am revenged
Of my Fidelio's death, and as thy tortures
Each hour increase, so shall my harmony
Till vengeance period give unto thy destiny.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I will discover thy hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: You are prevented, help, I sound, I fall.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: As low as hell there keep thy festival.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Hold murderous villain, all tortures man ere knew,
Shall be inflicted on thee.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Inhuman dog.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, I laugh at you.
Here's a preservative, against all your poisons
True balsamum for villainy,, who will soar high
First lesson that he learns, must be to die.
Here's precedent for him, you're slaves of Mahomet
Ungrateful curs, that have repaid me thus
For all the service that I have done for you,
He that hath brought more treasure to your shore
Then all Arabia yields, he that hath shown you
The way to conquer Europe, did first impart,
What your forefathers knew not, the seamans's art;
Which had they attained, this universe had been
One monarchy: may all your seed be damned
The name of Ottoman be the only scorn
And byword to all nations; may his own slaves
Tear out the bowels of the last remains
Unto his blood-propped throne, may ye cut each others throat ▪
Or may, o may the force of Christendom
Be reunited, and all at once require
The lives of all that you have murdered,
Beating a path out to Jerusalem,
Over the bleeding breasts of you and yours.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Unheard of monster.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Lastly, o may I be the last of all my country
that trust unto your treacheries , seducing treacheries ▪
All you that live by theft and piracies,
That sell your lives and souls to purchase graves,
That die to hell, and live far worse than slaves,
Let dying ward tell you that heaven is just,
And that despair attends on blood and lust:

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Down with the villain.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Tear the wretch piecemeal, throw his accursed limbs
Into the raging bowels of the sea.
His monument in brass we'll thus engrave,
Ward sold his country, turned Turk, and died a slave.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Who writes and thinks to please the general taste ▪
Where eyes and ears are fed, shall find he hath placed
His work with the fond painter, who did mend
So long, that striving to please others, gave no end
To his own labours; for us, and if not all
We know we have pleased some, whose judgements fall
Beyond the common rank, to whom we humbly yield
Ourselves and labours, they best deserve to shield
The worthy works of time, and with their view
To grace choice pens, and such we hope are you,
To whom we owe our toil, and willing give
All right in this, your favour makes it live.
Stand fair unto our ends then still, and crown
With gentle hand this work which now's your own.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
